comments.commentBody:
"Simple-city, itself"

F-Troop featured Larry Storch, who, along with Frank Gorshin and Rich Little, were three of the best impersonators ever, and all around the same time, each of whom appeared regularly on "The Ed Sullivan Show!"

WHH

I can't believe anyone would suggest allowing perfectly good fruits and vegetables go to waste simply because they are growing on bank-owned property. Rotting produce attracts rats and other vermin so these gatherers are simply providing free upkeep on the vacant property. This service is probably worth the price of a watermelon to the banker-owners.

I feel that many people are missing an important point.
Google didn't buy Motorola just for the sake of having a manufacturer, or even for the sake of patents.

Google bought Motorola in self defense. Microsoft was originally a potential buyer, but Google couldn't let that happen. Motorola owns the most important patents in the mobile world. Motorola owns the patent on the cell phone itself.

The other manufacturers understand this. They support Google. They know that Google was doing this for the sake of Android. Companies such as Samsung and HTC just about rely on Android now. If Microsoft had obtained Motorola, that would have been the end of Android, which would also have been the end of HTC and Samsung.

Google is not alienating other manufacturers. It is doing the opposite, saving Android, saving these numerous companies.

How many years (let alone American lives) have been invested in training the Iraqis to fight their own battles?  We like to think we've established a beachhead of democracy in the Middle East- in a country where Sunnis vote for Sunnis, Shiites for Shiites and Kurds for Kurds.  A country whose current leaders are scarcely less corrupt than the ones we got rid of (on their behalf).  Mr. Obama should not allow himself to let his commanders in the military talk him into staying one minute longer than had been agreed upon.  Iraq has been a mess since the day the country was created out of the ashes of the Ottoman Empire.  Let its citizens figure things out for themselves and decide whether they want to live with one another or kill one another.  Either way, it's none of our business.

"phase out" of what?  Centuries of tribal wafare in Iraq and Afghanistan?  Get out now, and leave the tribes to do what they do best, fight and kill one another. Haven't we and the "coalition of the willing" suffered enough.  For wshat?  For nothing.

When will our so-called leaders learn their limits and stop being so self-centered as to be believe that whatever they say is truth, especially when it comes to foreign relationships they obviously cannot control or understand. We spend our blood and treasure trying to do what and for whom? There is nothing to show for our foreign interventions but the enmity of a large part of the world. There is something terribly wrong and it is not out there but in here. And all the while that our attention is diverted by this pain and we grow poorer as a nation, others are taking economic control of the world. Ignorance is not bliss.

Sajwert
NH
August 15th, 2011
4:52 pm.... You got it wrong. We weren't monster slayer for the good of humanity. We're monster slayer for the good of Halliburton.

An important and consistent item in uniting these mass incidents is that they all have their origins in local or regional disputes. Ethnic tensions between Han and ethnic minorities, local (Party) corruption, thuggish behaviour on the part of the local constabulary, land disputes, environmental opposition to a factory - these all represent serious challenges to the Party's explicit goal of social harmony, but none of them represent a serious threat to Party control.

None of these protests could occur in the capital; Beijing is heavily policed, and when was the last time a mass demonstration occurred there? (The Falun Gong protest of more than a decade ago.) The censorship of the media, while not entirely comprehensive, nevertheless ensures that the official media ignore these incidents. Looking at CCTV's website, Dalian is mentioned in several dispatches in relation to China's new aircraft carrier; the closing of the chemical plant is explained as resulting from a storm, not a protest.

The incident reported in this article is an important piece of news about what is happening in China today. The article accurately notes some of the issues that have inflamed public opinion, and the many - many - problems that afflict China. But the Party remains ever vigilant to squash any public dissent against its rule, and it does not appear that there is any true mass discontent that imperils its rule.

now the chinese people should protest in large numbers against the vicious, barbaric abuse of non-human animals in china. a majority must be horrified and outraged. the extreme brutality there is an atrocity and is keeping the country from joining the civilized world. let's hope . . . .

Qadafi is a terrorist and tyrant, but he has billions so he can hire mercenaries, crowds for his own TV and also people who will post comments favorable to him.  The American Republican Party does the same thing. Incidentaly they will be very embarrassed when Qadafi falls as he bugged them going back to Reagan.

Mike #63:  Give Obama kudos for winding down the war in Iraq?  What about the other 4 wars he's started that we most definitely we will not "win"?  Swapping our soldiers out of one country and putting them in another is not a win for anyone.  Only when Americans stand together will we stop our involvement in these misguided ventures.

The whole time I was reading this I couldn't help but think of the role breastmilk might play--essentially the infant has an undeveloped immune system and depends on the mother to transfer passive immunity to the baby as well as stimulate the baby to develop his own immunity.  Take just one component--lactoferrin--binds with iron and competes with harmful bacteria, also stimulates growth of good bacteria-lactobacillus bifidus.  But most importantly it causes gut closure--acts as a type of 'glue' to make the gut less permeable to pathogens.  The GI tract of a breast fed infant is entirely different from a formula fed one--I'm wondering if we will discover that breastmilk plays a bigger role than we thought in immunity and microbial flora that lasts beyond infancy.

This was one of the best written articles I've read in the New York Times in a while. Now could Mr. Johnson please tackle other pressing and important subjects that we need explored clearly and directly by a journalist like him: what would (have) happen(ed) if the debt limit ceiling had not been raised; what the marginal federal income tax rates were under the varying presidents and what the US economy was under each rate; how effective certain federal approaches to economic crises (under Hoover, under FDR, under Eisenhower, under Reagan, under Clinton, etc.) have been; and so on? We need the kind of excellent, pellucid and informative reportage we see here on so many topics this paper seems to avoid like the plague. Why?

Helmet for children using motorbike with their parent / relatives is a must. The writer possibly met special case. I love the way they are travelling in Vietnam, though they hadn't taken their child to the best place.

Vietnam travel advisor
http://www.threeland.com

It is as if the staff has just given up as they get so many complaints from the visitors who stay there. In my case the main light in my room was permanently broken. My very dimly lit room was so dark I could not see my clothes to unpack. The telephone's information sheet was missing so had to go down to front desk to have them bring up an extra light to see by. The dead bolt in the door did not work. No safe. Went to the Hyatt the next day. Such a relief.

Fourteen "certified" letters stating $5,000 in wedding cash was actually a gift and not a loan? That's incredulous! (for a lousy $5k? Seriously? LOL) And there's talk of a "recovery"... wow, still laughing over that one

I had very good success with a tea made from half a dozen herbs. I got the the recipe from a book by Rosemary Gladstar. I got the herbs from a store called Rosemary's Garden, from which you can order online. I had to make the tea daily, and drink a quart of it over the course of the day, but it definitely ended the hot flashes. As long as I made and drank it faithfully, they did not return.

It's ESSENTIAL to point out that progestin is a SYNTHETIC molecule NOT made by the human body. Natural progesterone, which is made by the body and cannot be patented, has many beneficial effects. I have been using it in the cream for for more than 15 years. The pioneering work of John R. Lee, M.D. on this substance can be found with an online search.

There are also natural and synthetic estrogens. Don't be misled by those who are unwilling to make the distinction. Do your research and decide.

Thank you, Tara. Natural menopause causes estradiol and progesterone deficiencies, and estradiol and progesterone are exactly what need to be used to treat them. In my opinion, the safest and most effective way to do it is by prescribing bioidentical HRT to mimic women's hormone levels, rhythms, and cycles before they went into menopause. Come join me at www.facebook.com/menopausedoctor to help save the world from menopause.
Dr. Shira Miller

Forgot to mention this: for those who are worried about bone loss, check into STRONTIUM CITRATE. It's inexpensive, has no side effects, and remineralizes bone far better than calcium.  It should not be taken at the same time as calcium.  I take mine when I get up to use the bathroom in the middle of the night.  You can find it online easily.

I'm glad that the discourse about hormone replacement is veering back into sensible territory. Hormone use after menopause should always balance benefit and risk. Though I'm pleased that mainstream practice is shifting toward a less absolutist stance, I am alarmed by the amazing amount of misinformation about hormones. In particular, the quacks hocking "bioidentical" hormones are taking advantage of consumers' scientific illiteracy to rake in the profits. The FDA really needs to crack down on this utter nonsense.

Wow. I don't even know where to start. I must have started going through menopause around 38 or so. It hit me hard around 41. Who the heck calls them 'hot flashes'? Obviously some guy who never SUFFERED through them. Hot, cold, chills, pouring sweat off my brow. Forgetfulness to the point of being fired from my job! How can you be in sales and not remember anything. I mean I couldn't even remember if I had spoken to a client or not. sex life... well, that's a whole nother story too!
Found a great woman doctor who gave me the RX for bio-identicals and my life is completely different. I did not make this decision lightly. I am otherwise a vegetarian, organic, non drug taking lunatic. and I weigh about 100 pounds.
Bottom line. I am not planning on stopping these anytime soon. My life is totally different. It is livable now.

From what I've read, the Women's Health Initiative was so poorly designed -- large doses of artificial hormones for women mostly long past the onset of menopause -- that its results are of limited use. So it's a pity to see so many women suffer so badly based on elevated fears of an unlikely (though admittedly very serious) outcome.

It's so typical of our medical system -- a dumb "fad" of overprescribing something, followed by an equally dumb backlash.

I got my hormone levels tested in my 30s, and I know what's "normal" for me. I use low-dose estrogen and cyclical low-dose progesterone, and yes, low-dose TESTOSTERONE as well (why does nobody ever talk about this?!), monitored by an experienced gynecologist. I have suffered from moderate to severe depression my whole, and my emotional and mental well-being are important enough to me (and potentially fragile enough) that this is the right decision for me.

Amen to leaving the guy alone. Seriously; why do you feel the need to spring this on him? So you could add him to your pamphlet on the history of Jews in sports?
I had a Jewish, albeit never practiced, Grandmother. Often when I mentioned this in the company of a Jew I would see the eyes widen, the excitement as they could barely blurt out the question fast enough: "On your mother or father's side?" I got the feeling many of them were let down to hear it was my father's mother. What gives?

Okay, we have one more data point for this analysis. AJ was unable to finish six innings against the terrifying KC Royals lineup, giving up 10 hits and 3 runs in 5 2/3 innings.

Here's a new idea. Maybe the only reason he is still pitching is because Joe still feels unsure -- understandably -- that Colon and Garcia are going to make it through the rest of the season, including post-season, without injury or pitching collapse. If both of them are able to sustain their current performance then surely there is no way that AJ even makes an appearance in the final series of the regular season and in the post-season.

This shows us that all bodily processes are instructions being followed exactly. No accidents at all. This article further gives evidence  that all life is programmed. It may not be a pleasant situation, but how can we fight it?
